channel.title: Ramah: Good News Feed
channel.description: Positive news stories from around the world, filtered by sentiment analysis

item.title: How the West was won: K-pop's great assimilation gambit
item.description: Ejae's story could easily have ended there.

item.title: ‘My idea of heaven’: Madonna sings praises of artists’ paradise Margate
item.description: If you were to guess where Madonna goes on holiday, you might think Mustique or the Maldives – Margate probably would not make the list.

item.title: ‘The LED of heating’: cheap geothermal energy system makes US comeback
item.description: Nearly half a century ago, the US Department of Energy launched a clean energy experiment beneath the University of Minnesota with a simple goal: storing hot water for months at a time in an aquifer more than 100 metres below ground.

item.title: BBC vows to better reflect working-class audiences around UK
item.description: The BBC has committed to strengthening how it measures the ways audiences from different socio-economic and geographical backgrounds are portrayed and represented in its output.

item.title: Great Ormond Street surgeon harmed 94 children, review finds
item.description: Nearly 100 children suffered harm at the hands of a Great Ormond Street orthopaedic surgeon, a report has concluded.

item.title: EU proposals for free extra cabin bags on planes ‘lunatic idea’, says easyJet
item.description: EasyJet said proposals to enforce free additional cabin bags on planes across Europe are a “lunatic idea”, warning of fare rises and flight delays if legislation goes through.

item.title: Embrace the imperfect and don’t try to keep everyone happy: readers share their tips on doing less in 2026
item.description: At the beginning of the year, we asked experts on how we can go easier on ourselves.

item.title: Great Ormond Street doctor who botched surgery harmed nearly 100 children
item.description: Nearly 100 children were harmed by a Great Ormond Street Hospital limb reconstruction surgeon, a review has found.

item.title: Aryna Sabalenka hits out at umpire after grunting penalty in win over Svitolina
item.description: Aryna Sabalenka has dared officials to penalise her again for grunting after she rumbled over the top of Ukrainian Elina Svitolina in the Australian Open semi-final on Thursday to reach her fourth straight final at Melbourne Park.

item.title: Marty Supreme actress quits new film after casting backlash
item.description: Actress Odessa A'zion has pulled out of A24's latest film, Deep Cuts, after online backlash over her casting.

item.title: Blood, butter and boys in luv: BTS’s 20 best songs – ranked!
item.description: At the start of their career, BTS were marketed as a cross between a Korean idol band and a blinged-out rap act: “Our life is hip-hop,” offered band member Suga early on.

item.title: Urgent call to save Britain's oldest rollercoaster
item.description: The culture secretary is being urged to intervene and save Britain's oldest rollercoaster from closure.

item.title: Football as a content machine: 18 Champions League games was fun but overstuffed | Max Rushden
item.description: It’s half an hour after attempting to watch 18 football matches at the same time on the final match day of the Champions League group stage, so it’s still a little early to tell whether I think it was a brilliant night of football or not.

item.title: Stay on this stunning island for free... if you're willing to count puffins
item.description: A beautiful, remote island off the coast of southwest Wales could be your new home - as long as you are happy to count puffins.

item.title: Number of term-time school holiday fines hits another record high
item.description: A record 459,288 school holiday fines were issued in England last year, according to new figures from the Department for Education (DfE).

item.title: The ‘Rodman Rule’ threatens to undermine what makes the NWSL great | Jonathan Liew
item.description: Perhaps it was all worth it in the end.

item.title: Madonna's love letter to Emin and Margate
item.description: Queen of Pop Madonna has said Margate – once a declining seaside resort – is her "idea of heaven", and revealed her favourite Italian restaurant is also there.

item.title: Denmark ‘more optimistic’ about resolving US Greenland interest after latest talks – Europe live
item.description: Danish foreign minister Lars Løkke Rasmussen revealed he had “constructive” talks with the US over Greenland last night, saying that he is “slightly more optimistic today than a week ago” that a solution can be found.

item.title: Jonathan Trott: ‘I’d love to coach England one day. Definitely’
item.description: Think back to that team and Jonathan Trott was always the relatable one.

item.title: Is This Thing On? review – funny is as funny does in Bradley Cooper’s John Bishop-inspired tale
item.description: Comic actor Will Arnett finally gets a straight dramatic role and he’s playing … a comedian.

item.title: Nicheliving facing legal action over management of trust account
item.description: The WA Commissioner for Consumer Protection is alleging deregistered Perth builder Nicheliving improperly released customer funds from a trust account.

item.title: Lanarkshire to become 'one of the world's most advanced AI sites'
item.description: North Lanarkshire is to become the home of an artificial intelligence "growth zone", with the aim of turning the area into one of the world's most advanced AI sites.

item.title: US wellness industry demand for camel milk a win for Queensland farm
item.description: A south-east Queensland camel farm will begin exporting its milk to the United States for the first time in a landmark deal for the emerging industry.

item.title: UK wants 'sophisticated relationship' with China, Starmer tells Xi
item.description: British Prime Minister Keir Starmer has told Xi Jinping the UK wants to build a "sophisticated relationship" with China.

item.title: The rise of Fafo parenting: is this the end of gentle child rearing?
item.description: Mothers on social media are advocating a tough, no-nonsense approach to parenting.

item.title: Bill Belichick: A Super Bowl god's fall from grace
item.description: While the New England Patriots prepare for their 12th Super Bowl appearance, their former head coach Bill Belichick - widely considered to be the greatest professional football coach of all time - finds himself in an unlikely position: defending his legacy.

item.title: ‘A great marker’: Rosenior lauds young Chelsea side for comeback win at Napoli
item.description: Liam Rosenior praised his young Chelsea side’s ability to deal with adversity after they produced a spirited comeback against Napoli to reach the last 16 of the Champions League.

item.title: Paul Dano reacts to Tarantino criticism: ‘I was incredibly grateful that the world spoke up for me’
item.description: Paul Dano has responded to Quentin Tarantino’s scathing criticism of his acting abilities, thanking those who came to his defence after Tarantino called him a “weak, uninteresting guy” and “the limpest dick in the world”.

item.title: Napoli v Chelsea: Champions League – live
item.description: A huge win for Chelsea, another good win for Liam Rosenior.

item.title: Seven players ejected following brawl in 36ers win over Bullets
item.description: Bullets guard Hunter Maldonado and 36ers' Nick Rakocevic wrestled into empty chairs of the front row at Wednesday night's game, prompting an all-in scuffle.

item.title: Live: Victorian firefighters take advantage of better conditions as heatwave persists
item.description: NSW is on high alert for bushfires as towns across south-eastern Australia continue to swelter in the extreme heat.

item.title: Michael Mayo's 'Fly' is a soaring testament to his artistry and creative vision
item.description: With the release of his sophomore album, Fly, in October 2024, singer-songwriter and composer Michael Mayo ascended to new artistic heights.

item.description: A pilot programme aimed at diagnosing heart disease among people from ethnic minority backgrounds should be rolled out across the whole of the NHS, the doctors behind the initiative have urged.

item.title: Eating snow cones or snow cream can be a winter delight, if done safely
item.description: Experts say eating a bit of snow is probably fine if you live someplace with generally clean air, but staying away from plowed snow is a sensible precaution.

item.title: Wales' first minister refuses to support Keir Starmer

item.title: Shrinking season three review – Harrison Ford is the best thing about this unapologetically soapy show

item.title: Starmer vows to raise issues ‘that need to be raised’ with Xi amid push to free Jimmy Lai
item.description: Keir Starmer has said he will “raise the issues that need to be raised” on human rights with China’s leader, Xi Jinping, as he arrived in Beijing for the first trip to the country by a UK leader in eight years.

item.title: Spain will grant legal status to immigrants lacking authorization
item.description: BARCELONA, Spain — Spain's government announced Tuesday it will grant legal status to potentially hundreds of thousands of immigrants living and working in the country without authorization, the latest way the country has bucked a trend toward increasingly harsh immigration policies imposed in the United States and much of Europe.

item.title: Why is Greenland so rich in natural resources?
item.description: As recent manoeuvres over Greenland have made plain, this mostly ice-covered island contains some of the greatest stores of natural resources in the world, with huge volumes of oil and gas, rich deposits of rare-earth elements and rocks bearing gems and gold.

item.title: Football Daily | Harry Kane and the trolls that take aim at his staggering success
item.description: The most prolific striker on the planet for one of the biggest and most successful clubs in the world, a captain of his country who could possibly lift the World Cup this summer (ending what is now 60 years of hurt), a husband with four kids who is almost universally respected by fans, opponents and his peers, and a brand ambassador for global brands thanks to deals brokered by towering Mr 15% Charlie Kane, Harry Kane has a lot going for him.

item.title: Pubs and live music venues to get support after business rates backlash, Treasury confirms
item.description: The Treasury has unveiled a support package worth tens of millions of pounds for pubs and live music venues in England and Wales, in a climbdown that follows a fierce backlash against plans to overhaul business rates.

item.description: A company that seeks to disrupt the way in which data from space is received and transmitted has found some key investors and customers.

item.title: What is a heat pump and what grants are available?

item.title: 10 of the greatest songs by Sly Dunbar – from reggae classics to Grace Jones and Bob Dylan
item.description: It isn’t Sly Dunbar’s most spectacular performance as a drummer – although his playing is right in the pocket: listen to the lightness of his touch on the cymbals and the tightness of his occasional fills – but as recording debuts go, appearing on an early 70s reggae classic in your teens, a single that furthermore went to No 1 in the UK and sold 300,000 copies despite British radio’s disinclination to play it, is quite the impressive way to open your account.
